posts.name: Stappy
posts.cooked:
We were using our RoboRio 2.0 and suddenly we were faced with a red light (green at boot up and then red within seconds) which we figured was a power fault. One of the team members found a tiny bit of “Note” (orange rubber) in the SD card slot so we disassembled and retrieved the piece of rubber. We put it back together and tried it again and still red. We then bought a 64 gig XC card and formatted, and tried again. Still no luck.

Code seems to run and it seems to work but still have the power fault light on.

Any ideas?

posts.name: Sidd Rao
posts.cooked: Yea,the power light turning red indicates a power fault. Vacuum out all the ports on your roborio, sometimes little metal shavings get into those giant ports, bridge some pins and create a short.

posts.name: James
posts.cooked:
We got that last year during a competition (luckily it did not affect our robot but we didn’t use the 6v rail which showed a short on DS). It turned out to be a very small piece of metal that you could barely see inside the middle of the roborio.

We fixed it by opening the case and using an air compressor.

posts.name: DIBBY
posts.cooked:
We just had this issue on a roborio 2.0 that was supposedly “broken”. I recommend booting up the roborio and connecting directly to it via a printer cable (USB B to USB A) and pull up driver station.

On the very last tab on the side, it’ll show you data like CAN utilization, faults, etc etc. You can actually tell which power rail currently has a fault, and then take an air compressor and blow those rails.

In our case, we actually had to lift up the plastic black cover that goes above all the pins slowly with a small flathead screwdriver to get the last metal shard out which caused our power fault.

posts.name: Stappy
posts.cooked: Did and done, same results. The boards have a conformal coating on them so for the most part they should not be able to be shorted out BUT… it got a thorough cleaning including under the heat sink that has a sticky coating that holds garbage under it.

posts.name: Stappy
posts.cooked: We will check that in the software Monday night.

posts.name: neev dadhania
posts.cooked:
quite possibly:

in all seriousness though, if youre feeling REALLY adventurous, we once fixed a roborio 1.0 by taking it apart via the screws on the back and then firing the inside with a little compressed air. might work for you but havent looked at how “take-apart-able” the 2.0 is

posts.name: Michael Maynard
posts.cooked:
As has been said above. The power light turning red indicates a short on one of the Rio power busses.

The first place to start is in the driver station, the last tab (I believe it is a lightning bolt) this will tell you which rail the fault is on and make it easier to track down.

Next vacuum over the relevant rails (never blow out the Rio with compressed air as it can actually force the contaminate further into the case.

If this does not work you will need to disassemble the Rio (four screws on the back of the case). Visually inspect the rails for any contaminants and remove as necessary.

If this does not fix it, carefully lift the black bases that are at the bottom of the pins using a small flat head screwdriver (*note that these components are delicate and if not lifted up carefully and evenly will break apart) Inspect the pins and remove any contaminants.

If this fixes the problem reassemble the Rio and tape over any unused ports (there are also some 3D printed covers out there if you prefer those, we usually just stick to the tape though as it is more modular) Also ensure that you cover any electronics with trash bags or other coverings while drilling on the robot to help keep debris out of them. It takes more time when setting up to drill the hole, but it takes even longer to diagnose and fix a Rio short.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
nevadexehs:

might work for you but havent looked at how “take-apart-able” the 2.0 is

It’s easy to disassemble and reassemble about the same as a rio1.

Definitely reach out to NI on their support form, possibly to request an RMA.

If you vaccum the inside out meticulously, then hook it up only with power and USB, it really should not have that fault.

Anecdotally, the RIO2 seems much more prone to failing in this way than the Rio 1 in our teams experience.

posts.name: Stappy
posts.cooked: Basically four screws and a big circuit board falls out. All in one packaging. Like I said, the little heat sink strip holds quite a bit of garbage. We spent quite awhile digging stuff out of it including an almost microscopic piece of “note” down in the USB. That orange garbage gets everywhere.

posts.name: neev dadhania
posts.cooked: there is cheeto dust in the ceiling tiles in our robotics room
